qas.question: What can be considered for the special case of systems which are closed to transfers of matter?
The portion of energy which does not do work during the transfer is called what?
Give one example of how energy can be transferred between systems?

answers.text: transmission of electromagnetic energy via photons

qas.question: What can be considered for the typical case of systems which are opened to transfers of matter?
The portion of energy which works during the transfer is called what?

plausible_answers.text: transmission of electromagnetic energy via photons

qas.question: Give one example of how energy cannot be transferred between systems?
the inductive transer of what kind of energy?
what are physical collisions which don't transfer kinetic energy?

context: <a0_0><b3_0>Energy transfer<b3_0/><a0_0/> can be considered for the special case of systems which are closed to transfers of matter. The portion of the energy which is transferred by conservative forces over a distance is measured as the work the source system does on the receiving system. The portion of the energy which does not do work during the transfer is called <a1_0><b4_0>heat<b4_0/><a1_0/>.[note 4] Energy can be transferred between systems in a variety of ways. Examples include the <a2_0><b5_0>transmission of electromagnetic energy via <b7_0>photons<b7_0/><b5_0/><a2_0/>, physical collisions which transfer kinetic energy,[note 5] and the conductive transfer of <b6_0>thermal<b6_0/> energy.
